ud3.7:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
ud3.7:1.3: Now at that time Venerable Mahākassapa was staying in the Pipphali cave. Having entered a certain state of immersion, he sat cross-legged for seven days without moving.
ud3.7:1.4: When seven days had passed, Mahākassapa emerged from that state of immersion.
ud3.7:2.1: Now at that time five hundred deities were ready and eager for the chance to offer alms to Mahākassapa.
ud3.7:2.2: But Mahākasspa refused those deities. In the morning, he robed up, took his bowl and robe, and entered Rājagaha for alms.
ud3.7:3.1: Now at that time Sakka, lord of Gods, wished to give alms to Mahākassapa.
ud3.7:3.2: Having manifested in the appearance of a weaver, he worked the loom while the demon maiden Sujā fed the shuttle.
ud3.7:3.4: Then, as Mahākassapa wandered indiscriminately for alms-food in Rājagaha, he approached Sakka’s house.
ud3.7:3.5: Seeing Mahākassapa coming off in the distance,
ud3.7:3.6: Sakka came out of his house, greeted him, and took the bowl from his hand. He re-entered the house and filled the bowl with rice from the pot.
ud3.7:3.7: That alms-food had many tasty soups and sauces.
ud3.7:3.9: “Now, what being is this who has such psychic power?”
ud3.7:3.12: Knowing this, he said to Sakka,
ud3.7:3.14: don’t do such a thing again.”
ud3.7:3.15: “But sir, Kassapa, we too need merit!
